page.lettertext:
fol.32r
May it please your good L: to that effect
at
I writte
e 14 of this mo-
neth there have bin certaine deputed in
e meeting of
e
States
, to
come in conference with me about my proposition and this they have
delyvered from
e rest of the Assemblie, That they were greatly
perplexed, through those demandes of restitution, not knowing how to
frame
e course of their proceeding. For though they can not but ac-
knowledge, and doe it most willingly
at through her
Ma
ties
succors,
next to God), they are in farre better state of securitie and assu-
rance, then they have bin heeretofore for many yeares togither, yet
they have not attayned to
at
[.]
abilitie and power, as they can ther-
withall discharge their debte unto her Ma
tie
. They alleage many
lettes, but nothing soe muche, as
e intollerable burthen of their extra-
ordinarie subsidies, which have growen upon them more and more,
for these 4 or 5 yeares, and are raised of late to a very highe
summe, occasioned in parte by their offensive exploites, and partly
by their often and chargeable
relieving
relieving
of
e
F
r
King
in his mani-
fold distresses. By reason whereof they doe inferre at
e chiefe contri-
buting
Provinces
are farre in arrerages, and pay excessive su
m
es of
mony for
e use of
at they have borrowed. And though it might
be surmised
at they have ayded
e Kinge, not soe muche in regarde of
his urgent necessitie, as
de gayete de coeur
, and to winne his affection,
for hidden requestes, yet they protest therupon w
th
very great vehemencie,
at they were evermore
farre
from any suche jollitie, and would not have
him to enjoye a foote in their contrey. For that which drew them on, to
helpe and assist him, was
e g
na
ll consideration of his condition and their
owne: and they made this account,
at for as muche as her Hig
es
did
support him w
th
her forces, if they in lyke manner should strayne their
estate to uphold him a little, it would both be a meanes to save him from
falling and to divert
e Enemie from themselves: whereas otherwise, if
those of
e League had prevayled against him, these Provinces at
e last
must have booren
alone
e weight of these warres and then bin subject in the
ende, and her Ma
tie
no lesse, to an apparant great nomber of most pe-
rillous inconveniences. And whereas it may be said
argued,
at their late
reduction of soe many good townes, hath both greatly assured
e State of these
Provinces and richely augmented their generall meanes wherby they are
inabled to some portion of remboursem
t
, they make remonstrance to
e
contrarie, as
if
in every of those Provinces they had rather bin sur-
charged, then any thing eased hitherto: and that by reason of
e excessive charges of new garrisons, of necessarie reparations,
fortifications, and other extraordinarie occasions, and because
fol.32v
the boores contribution is
but
very little bettered of
at it w[as in former]
tymes. Moreover they say they finde it in debating [very]
doubtfull and dangeros in what sorte they should proceed [for the]
answearing of her Hig
es
to my proposition. For in a [mater of]
at qualitie to make a resolute answear, w
th
out
e privi[tie and]
good lyking of
e Provinces and people, they dare not [of them-]
selves, and it will not stande for good: and then to ac[quaint]
e vulgar sorte w
th
her Ma
ties
demandes, were to make it [also]
knowen to all
e Enemies Provinces, and soe to all men in g[eneral]
whereupon it would be bruited, That her Hig
es
hath with[drawen]
her accustomed assistance, and hath requyred present
of her monies disbursed: which they are mightily all afra[id would]
turne very quickly to their infinit detriment: aswell for [that the Ene-]
mie who is now in
all
apparance at a very great after deale, w[ill be hear-]
tened therby, and put in practise newe designes, and m[ultiplie]
his forces by all possible meanes, as because on
e other sy[de the]
people of these Contries will be cast downe in courage, [and despaire]
of withstanding
e puissance of
e Spaniard. For wh[ere they]
might have hoped after soe many yeares endevo
rs
, [so large]
contributions, and soe many late victories, to reape so[me solace,]
and ease of their burdens and travels, if now they [should per-]
ceave
at for many yeres hereafter, their taxes and [exactions will]
fall a great deale more heavie, then they have bin [heertofore]
first by meanes of their ordinarie and extraordinarie [charges of the]
warres, and then by
e losse of her Ma
ties
forces, and [most of all]
by this remboursem
t
, it were greatly to be doubted
at [they will runne]
a wronge course in
e heate of theyr dislyke. [For that is it]
which they affirme to be a principall cause, of the[ir late inter-]
tayning of this English regiment,
at
e actions of the[ir warres]
might be countenaunced alwayes w
th
e name and [opinion, and]
reporte of assistance continued to them by her Hig
es
[in so muche]
as they pretend
at for
e most
e meaner mutlitude ar[e no other-]
wise yet informed, but
at they serve as a parte of Aux[iliarie]
forces, and are in pay of her Ma
tie
. Soe as alwayes they [have]
founde in all
e tyme of these troubles,
at they have not only m[ade]
warres, and annoyed
e Enemie w
th
e aide of men and mony
but with very opinions and conceats,
at they were favoured [and]
protected by
e greatnesse of her Ma
tie
. These [thinges]
thus delyvered they sayd they were also charged, to participat
fol.34r
[unto] me
e
Scottish Kinges
l
re
, and his request by
Coronel Stuart
, whereof
they told me
e contents, and then read
e l
re
to me, and
e Coronels
Instructions translated into Frenche, which I send heere inclosed copied
truely by
e originals. Their speeche unto me upon it was this in
substance, That they for themselves were nothing well instructed
of
e state of
e Kinge, nor of those proceedinges of his Rebels, but
if it were soe as those wrytings imported, and they had further
understoode by
e Coronels relation, there was great occasion offered
to moove her Ma
tie
and them, and as many as are embarked in
this co
m
on cause together, to heede in good season, and to affourd
the King a rounde assistance. For sith
e Enemie spedde no better
in his former attempt all men might might conjecture
at he would
not lette slippe a fitte opportunitie, to make a breache by Scotland,
soe to compasse all at ease both heere in and in France, all his
other designes. For their owne partes, they for their abilitie
would be willing to doe any thing, to meete w
th
these dangers, not
sturred unto yt, as some men might imagine, for some secret purpose
but onely in regarde of
e generall cause: which provoked them at
first to assist
e
Kinge of Fraunce
, and doth move them at this
tyme to tender
e Estate of
e Scottish King, and if her Hig
es
in
lyke maner in her Irish co
m
otions, should have any kynde of neede
to use theyr meanes or service there, they would stretch theyr strenght
[to]
e uttermost to accomplish her desyres. And this they uttered w
th
[w]ordes of great assurance and earnestnesse. They concluded in
[fin]e,
at first for
e mater of remboursem
t
,they would laye their
[al]legations open to her Hig
es
, before suche tyme, as they would publish
her message to
e Provinces, and would beseech her to ballance
e
weight of those reasons w
th
her Princely consideration.
They expected w
th
in a sevenight
e coming of
e Deputies of
Gueldres
and
Overissel,
who were buised in those quarters in persuading
e people
to this yeares contribution. Assoone as they were returned, I should
presently receave their answear in wryting: they prayed
me
e whyle to
intimat soe muche by l
re
to her Ma
tie
, lest perhaps it should be deemed
that they have an intention to use some delay. And then secondely
they requested in
e name of
e States, sith they could not well deter-
mine what course to embrace in
e fores
d
motion of
e K. of Scottes
at I in
at respect would franckely communicat my counsayle unto
them, to witte what I thought would best accorde, both w
th
her
Ma
ties
acceptance, and
e pleasuring of
e Kinge, because it was
fol.34v
theyr full desyre to proceede in those actions, w
th
good corresp[ondence, and]
not otherwise.
I made my aunswear to this effect
T[hat as-]
touching those pointes which they had proposed, to manife[st]
their want
and
of
abilitie
therein
, they might very well [presume,]
at her Hig
es
had examined those reasons already and [that their]
Agent
in England had pleaded them often, and at [she thought]
them insufficient, to dissuade her from her purpose. [For]
where they doe complaine
at
e Annuall burden of their [extraordi-]
narie Contributions doth lye soe heavie upon
e Contrey, [it was]
easie to demonstrat,
at
e contrey was in case to perfourm [a grea-]
ter matter. They have now in Contribution, [which they]
had not heeretofore when they treated w
th
her Ma
tie
[the greatest]
parte of
Brabant
and
Flanders;
e Omnelandes,
e [
Drent
, the
Twent
,]
Linghen,
e landes of
Limbourgh
and
Valkemborgh,
and [sundrie]
other quarters, which yeald them every moneth a very [rich revenue,]
besydes
at Guelderland, Ru
t
phan, and also Overissel doe [pay a]
farre greater subsidie, then in former tymes. They a[re also enri-]
ched exceedingly by reason of
her
their
imposts in townes lately [taken,]
as in
Nieumeghen
Zutphan
,
Devent
r
Steenwich,
Breda,
[
Hulst
]
Steenberghen
Groeninghen
w
th
others fortes and places of [special]
importance. Moreover they have had of late years [a wonder-]
full augmentation of their Customes, and tolles, by mean[es of their]
fishing, and trafficke by Sea, which was never soe gre[at as it is]
at this p
nt
, nor this contrey was ever soe full of inh[abitants, nor]
frequented of forraines, soe as hardly houses in [most places can]
be hyred for money. These were evident and k[nowen meanes,]
as there were many more besydes, to shew
e wealth [of these contreis]
at if
e revenues thereof be not greater
en
e charges, [yet no doubt]
they are equivalent. They could not judge other[wise, howsoever]
some discoursed, but
at her Ma
tie
both spake and [thought very ho-]
norably of their succo
rs
sent for
France.
[Nevertheles]
it is a great
pre
presumption
at it comes of great abun[dance]
when any Contrey shall make warres and winne upon
e [Enemie,]
and yet spare of their stoare to helpe other Princes. For w[here]
her Hig
es
had good cause after soe many yeares aide, the con[sump-]
tion of soe much treasure, and
e loose of
e lives of soe many of [her]
subjectes, for defence of
ese contries to calle for restitution.
But how much
she
she
would demande to be presently restored, I coul[d]
fol.33r
not say upon certaintie, though I thought it might be lesse, then they
peradventure made account. For soe
at order might be taken
for good payment heere after, it would suffise for
e p
r
esent,
by some little good beginning, to shew their thanckefull inclina-
tion to give her good satisfaction. And where they made
it a question, whether it were expedient, as their present state
standeth to imparte soe muche unto
e people, it did but cary a
shew of a dilatorie answear. For her Ma
ties
demande
was justly made and kindly presented, and if
e Deputies of
e
Provinces would accompanie
e same, with suche kinde of persuasi
o
s,
as they knew in their wisdomes how to appropriat, it would either
be accorded or nothing ill interpreted
. As concerning
those affaires which Coronel Stuart did negotiat, it was out of
my Commission, to saye any thing unto them, and for ought I could
conjecture, they were unsignified to her Ma
tie
And therfore if they
pleased to accept of my advise as privately given, and not otherwise
I knowe not how they could doe better, then to wryte unto her of it,
and to crave her good direction: as alsoe for heereafter not to deale
with
at Contrey in any cause of consequence, but w
th
her Ma
ties
fore-
knowledge, and with continuall correspondence. My aunswear
herein and
e rest of my speeches to
e point of restitution they promi-
sed to signifie in their publicke assemblie, seeming every waye to me
to allow of my advise, as fitte for them to follow for
e maters of
Scotland. Coronel Stuart in privat co
m
unic
ao
n hath intrea-
ted me to further his message to
e States, declaring how neere it
concerned her Ma
tie
aswell as
e Kinge, and
at questionlesse my
[ser]vice would be gratefull to them both, w
th
other pertinent inducem
ts
.
[U]pon which I inquyred whether
e K: had imparted
at matter to her
Ma
tie
. His aunswear was
at her Hig
es
was acquainted w
th
e State
[o]f
e Kinge, and sawe he should be forced to crave
e aide of his
frindes, for whiche shee could not but allow of his proposall to
e
States. But yet otherwise also he thought
at she knewe it longe
agoe. Whereunto I replied
at I was sure she had notice of his
publicke employment, before I came out of
England,
but I did verylie
beleeve
at his errand to this people was unknowen to her Hig
es
.
Howsoever it were not having had in charge to deale in his affaires,
I was to praye him to excuse me, if I were not very forwarde,
fol.33v
onely this I would promise,
at if
e States by waye of [talke should]
happen to aske me, I would wishe them to wryte and [take advise]
of her Ma
tie
, and
at for many respectes; but most [of all to]
prevent misconstructions and jalousies. For he kn[ewe well]
enough
at neighbors Princes, though they live in good [amitie,]
will conceave a little jalousie of one anothers actions [and]
whether her Ma
tie
nowe in this p
nt
case, all kinde of [circum-]
stances weighed (which I would Leave to his discre[tion to]
examine throughly) might not thincke somewhat s[trange of ]
e Kinges proceedinges, and more peradventure of
e S[tates, if]
they should yelde to his demandes, and never aske any [question]
of her Ma
ties
lyking, he himself might be judge. [As for me]
my endevo
rs
should tende to doe good offices, and there c[ould not]
be a better to my little insight, then to minister all o[ccasions]
of mutuall intelligence, between her Ma
tie
and the
m
K.
, a[nd the States]
of these Contries. I cannot tell very well howe he [liked of]
my counsayle, but yet me thought but indifferently.
Nevertheles he bare me in hande,
at both it pleased [him well,]
and he
bo
would presently dispatch to move
e K. and [the Chancellor]
to addresse to
t
effect some l
re
s to her Ma
tie
, which he [also affir-]
med to be requyred by
e States, whose remonstrance [unto him was]
chiefly directed, to shew how muche it would please [the generality]
heere, to understand
at
e King would frame himself in [all his purpo-]
ses to give her Ma
tie
good contentm
t
. I had [this talke with]
Coronel Stuart somewhat after
at I had spoken w
th
tho[se that were sent]
from
e States unto me: who as I am persuaded told [him presently]
upon yt, what I had signified unto them, with such [token of appro-]
bation, as it caused him
e sooner to yeeld to me in [my former speech.]
Being asked sins of a frinde, howe he went [forward with]
his suite, he said he could not tell, for
at he fou[nd himself]
crossed, whether he meant it of me I am not certaine, [but I suspect]
it by divers conjectures. I am told by some about [him, that he]
hath promised to bring ten thousand Scottes to serve against
e [Turke,]
if
e Princes of
Germanie
will give him intertainem
t
, for which [he]
and his friendes are earnest sollicitors, and as I am informed, ha[ve]
a grant in a maner, so
at now he doth but treate about
e assurance
of his paye, for which he requyreth bondes of some of
e Hanse to[wnes.]
fol.35r
Of the death of
Ernestus
I thincke your L: hath notice, and had it
assoone as we in this place, bcause o
r
first intelligence came by
l
res
out of
Zeeland.
It giveth occasion of muche discoursing,
whether every thing considered it will prove beneficial or hurtefull
to this Contrey. But
e most are gladde of it, and they take it
for a blessing. The rather, for
at it comes in a tyme, when
e mutined Italians are discontented a fresh and others sins have
begon to follow their Example, in dyvers places of
e Frontiers, besydes
at every where, we heare
at aswell
e Co
m
ons, as nobilitie were never
more distasted of
e Spanish gouvernement. Such opportunities as
these are not offered oftentymes, to ruine downe right such an Enemie
as
e Spaniard, and if
e power of this people were but halfe
soe muche more, as it is at this p
nt
, they would thincke to
e ffect it in very shorte tyme. That which I advertised
in my laste to yo
r
L: of
e Carriadge of mony out of Zeland into
Scotland was signified unto me by one of
e States; but inquyring
of it sins, it hath bin told me by others
at
e money was taken up in
royals of plate, by
e marchant
of
e Minte, to whome
e minting
of mony is farmed in Scotland, and
at it was for their owne use.
And thus excusing my lenght with
e occasions presented, and
besseching your L: to make report unto her Ma
tie
of as muche as is
convenient, I take my humble leave.
